basics.name: Robert John Holash
basics.label: Scientist, Muscle Physiology, Computational biology
basics.summary: A Canadian born research scientist, currently working at the University of Calgary in the fields of Health and Human Performance

work.name: Faculty of Kinesiology, University of Calgary
work.summary: Dr. John Holash is a recognized expert in the fields of Exercise Physiology, Muscle Physiology, and Computational Biology, currently serving as an assistant professor at the University of Calgary in the Faculty of Kinesiology's Human Performance Lab. His commitment to understanding and optimizing human performance is deeply rooted in both his academic pursuits and personal experiences as an athlete, adventurer and a researcher.

work.name: Faculty of Kinesiology, University of Calgary
work.summary: Design, develop and maintain expert computational solutions for research problems within the Human Performance Lab (HPL)

work.name: University of Calgary
work.summary: Technical lead, software designer, and analyst for Kinesiology IT

publications.name: Technological Breakthroughs in Sport
publications.summary: An encyclopedia article outlining the potential impacts of artificial intelligence (AI) and virtual reality (VR) on current sports science

publications.name: A Ramp- Versus Step-Transition to Constant-Work Rate Exercise Decreases Steady-State Oxygen Uptake
publications.publisher: Medicine and Science in Sport and Exercise
publications.summary: To investigate whether a ramp-to-constant-work rate (rCWR) transition compared to a square-wave-to-constant-work rate (CWR) transition within the heavy-intensity domain can reduce metabolic instability and decrease the oxygen cost of exercise.

publications.name: In support of the continued use of the term anaerobic threshold
publications.summary: We would like to suggest that the appropriate meaning of the term ‘anaerobic threshold’is the highest intensity that can be sustained exclusively by aerobic metabolism, as suggested previously (Svedahl & MacIntosh, 2003). Above this intensity there is a sustained contribution of energy from glycolysis

publications.name: A stochastic simulation of skeletal muscle calcium transients in a structurally realistic sarcomere model using MCell
publications.summary: Using MCell software, we developed a realistic myofibrillar half-sarcomere model that successfully reproduced and visualized the asymmetric calcium distribution during skeletal muscle contraction, aligning with experimental and previous simulation data.
